Award.AwardTitle: US Government Support for IAI Core Budget 2014-2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award serves as the U.S. Government contribution to the 2015 to 2017 core budget of the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI). The IAI is an intergovernmental institution whose core budget is funded through contributions from its 19 member countries, including the USA. The funding represents the US voluntary contribution to the IAI as set by agreed to by the USG, and will be used to cover 59% of the IAI Directorate international staff salaries and travel costs, travel costs for the 10-member Scientific Advisory Committee of the IAI, and part of the IAI's publication budget. The present proposal covers the US contribution for three years.

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in the essential role of the IAI and its core funding in realizing the IAI's objectives to implement regional cooperation for interdisciplinary research on global environmental challenges; to conduct or select for sponsorship (based on peer review) scientific projects and training of regional relevance which cannot be conducted by any single country or institution; to link research institutions of the region to global programs; to improve the scientific and technical capabilities and research infrastructure of the countries of the region; to foster standardization, collection, analysis and exchange of scientific data; and to provide scientific information to government towards public policy on global environmental challenges.
The IAI implements its science programs using calls for proposals, peer reviews and post-award monitoring. In addition it has become active in developing durable networks of institutions and researchers across disciplines and countries, and is engaging in analysis and synthesis of the IAI's varied science output. The IAI develops science and policy strategies in consultation with member countries, and collects and processes science output to contribute to informed decision making. During the three year period of support requested here, the IAI will complete two science programs, provide final analysis, reporting and an in-depth synthesis of the science and policy implications. The synthesis of science-decision making links will be published in a variety of publications for different audiences, and will be edited by IAI staff and other experts. A strategic planning process has been initiated and a new cooperative science program will be developed. Five training programs have been scheduled and others will be developed. The broader implications that go beyond the science content of the networks lie in the building of institutional capacities in the region to manage large collaborative science projects. Over the next 3 years, the IAI will continue its task of linking research and education activities across disciplines, and explore opportunities generated by the international networking to insert science into the decision process of its member countries. An important effort will therefore be to engage member countries in the science and its translation into a form relevant for decision makers at all levels.

Background
The IAI has been listed by the State Department as an international organization within the meaning of the Federal Employees International Organization Service Act, covered by 5 U.S.C. 3343 and 5 U.S.C. 3581.

Core Budget support, for which this proposal is submitted, allows the operation of the Directorate of the IAI. Currently, the IAI Directorate is hosted by Uruguay on the campus of the Technological Laboratory of Uruguay in Montevideo where the IAI Directorate functions as an internationally recognized juridical personality, with the corresponding privileges and immunities granted by the Government of Uruguay.

Core Budget commitment pledges are made by the all Parties to the Agreement Establishing the IAI: Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Jamaica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and the USA. Amounts are arrived at by consensus at an annual meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the IAI Agreement.

The IAI is a U.S. initiative to stimulate cooperative research on global change issues among the scientific institutions of the Americas. The National Science Foundation is the lead U.S. Government agency designated by the White House to carry out U.S. responsibilities within the IAI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Directorate’s responsibilities are listed under Article VIII of the Agreement establishing the IAI. It acts as the primary administrative organ of the IAI by implementing long-range plans and strategies and the financial policies, annual program, and budget. It is also responsible for the day-to-day operations of programs and policies approved by the IAI Conference of the Parties.

The development and implementation of IAI sponsored interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary global-change research  has produced innovative results to inform policy makers and communities to generate more effective policies.

The Directorate plays a key role in ensuring that projects contain the mechanisms necessary to undertake trans and interdisciplinary science particularly with regard to the active participation of important stakeholders. Accordingly, special care is taken to encourage the participation of a  broad spectrum of sciences in all projects: physical and natural, social and human, engineering and medical.

Scientific activities are buttressed by capacity building activities and workshops. Of these, workshops organized with Associates of the IAI, those with the AAAS have been especially successful. The Schools of Advanced Sciences is another example of successful capacity building executed in collaboration with universities from São Paulo state in Brazil, which are fully funded by FAPESP. For 3 consecutive years, the Schools trained over 300 graduate students and addressed important global change themes, such as oceans, climate and nitrogen cycles. Virtual workshops were designed and used to introduce project researchers on transdisciplinarity using information and communication technologies. These workshops provided the space for policy makers and stakeholders to work jointly with researchers to increase the relevance and applicability of their science.

Additionally, the Directorate acts as a clearing-house and coordinator among the different IAI projects, which are collaborative and multinational in nature.  The Directorate aligns with organizations to increase complementarity of efforts in the region. Some examples include, the strengthening of IAI’s collaboration with the Belmont Forum, Future Earth, and FAPESP in the design and implementation of joint science projects, capacity building and science-policy activities. Moreover, in September 2018 the IAI signed an MoU with AAAS to promote Science Diplomacy in the Americas. Furthermore, the IAI is negotiating an MoU with the OAS to join forces on sustainability science and policy for the region. The IAI and the OAS will identify synergies and information gaps to collaborate in sharing and disseminating environmental and scientific information as well as in the area of science diplomacy.

Since 2012, CRN3 involves 15 of the IAI's 19 Parties with 17 Principal Investigators and 95 co-investigators in 90 institutions in the Americas. CRN3 projects have leveraged an additional US$ 11.38 million during the last year reported. In the last phase of CRN3 projects, the Directorate assisted researchers and stakeholders in ensuring the development of their work plans and the use of funds achieved solution-oriented results within the context of the IAI’s high standard of scientific excellence. Furthermore, these projects were successful in enhancing the inclusion of social dimensions and are reflective of the American scientific community’s efforts to work collaboratively to better understand global problems and propose viable adaptation and mitigation strategies. 

A Small Grants Program on the Role of Ecosystem Services in Adaptation to Global Change for Human Wellbeing (SGP-HW) was launched by the Directorate. International teams of researchers  have submitted proposals for grants up to USD 200,000. Proposals include transdisciplinary research on global change issues and are also based on participatory design to ensure the full inclusion of policy makers  and other stakeholders.  The Directorate received full proposals by May 2018, and has completed a preliminary filtering of the proposals. A final list of projects to be funded will be completed by 17 December.

The Directorate was also able to link its science and capacity program with regional and international global change research programs. Many of these programs are guided by multilateral environmental agreements, organizations or institutions. As a result, a number of joint programs with United Nations administered environmental conventions, programs and specialized agencies were realized.

During this intersessional period, the Directorate also made special efforts to include indigenous peoples and local communities in its capacity building programs and workshops with a view to facilitate their full and equitable participation in the activities of the IAI. An example was the IAI Professional Development Seminar on transdisciplinary approaches to integrating policy and science for sustainability, which had the participation of representatives from Canada’s first nations and of indigenous communities from Chile.  SGP-HW pre-selected teams also include indigenous communities.
